resources.string: Important Notice: This identification is not guaranteed. Do not consume mushrooms based on this result.
⚠️ Remember: Always consult an expert before eating wild mushrooms.
Learning the Key Features for Both Safe and Dangerous Species

DANGER: YOU CANNOT TRUST SIMPLE RULES.\nMany deadly mushrooms look almost identical to edible ones. The only safe way to identify a wild mushroom for consumption is with a field guide and the guidance of an expert. When in doubt, throw it out!
Key Identification Features for All Mushrooms

1. Cap & Gills/Pores\n- Gills: Look at the color, attachment, and spacing. Example: Oyster Mushroom has white gills extending down the stem, Death Cap has free white gills.\n- Pores: Some mushrooms (e.g., King Bolete) have sponge-like undersides. Still, some pore-bearing mushrooms are poisonous.

2. Stem, Ring, & Volva
- Stem: Note shape, texture, and color.
- Ring (Annulus): Skirt-like ring on the stem. Example: Shiitake has none, Death Cap has it.
- Volva: Cup at the stem base. Critical feature of Amanita. Dig entire mushroom to check.

3. Spore Print
- Spore print color is key to distinguishing edible vs deadly.
- Example: Meadow Mushroom: chocolate brown; Morel: light yellow; Destroying Angel: white.
- How: Place cap gills-down on paper, cover with bowl, wait a few hours.

Red Flags to Always Watch For:
- Death Cap Trio: White Gills + Ring + Volva. Likely deadly Amanita. Do not eat.
- Any Mushroom with White Gills and a White Spore Print. Avoid unless expert.
- No-Go Categories: All small brown mushrooms (LBMs) and mushrooms that bruise blue.
